Air runs off of cell towers that only provide “dynamic”ip addresses (meaning that the ip address changes every day). This caused my apps(Hulu live and Utube live) to change location every day.  Got locked out of Hulu because of the 4 locations change cap. Requires “static” ip address.  Tech support said this cannot be changed.  So… back it went to att.A month later I received a-bill for $121.71 ( two months) .  I called to make sure we are not charged to card.  Charges waived. Had to call to get this fixed since automated email would destroy my credit rating.  They (billing) saidagain to ignore any automated emails as account will be closed ( it should have been closed the first time).

I had AT&T internet service at a rural location, and it has been consistently terrible from the start. I grew tired of constantly having to call them to complain about it (as they couldn't do anything to make it better anyway). Daily, we had to reset the router to get it working again, and the speed varied between 1 and 15 Mbps (averaging around 8 when it felt like working). After enduring a couple of years of this "service," I was relieved to find that T-Mobile offered a more affordable solution.When I called AT&T to discontinue the service, the salesperson suggested "suspending" the account instead of closing it. This sounded good at the time since I was unsure whether T-Mobile would be worse than them. Unfortunately, the salesperson failed to mention that the service would automatically resume after 3 months.T-Mobile ended up being three times faster (without the resets!) for less than half the cost of AT&T. Needless to say, there was no reason to reactivate AT&T service. However, they still had my credit card on file, and it turns out they had been charging me for over 5 months—over $100/mo—before I caught it on my credit card statement. And please note that when I went online to check the account it was shown as disabled!When I called them to address the issue, they acknowledged the mistake and mentioned that it would take multiple weeks to rectify, promising a callback. I explicitly told them to close the account. Unfortunately, they never called me back. After seeing yet another bill, I called them again. This time they couldn't charge it since I had them remove my credit card from the file. During the call, they agreed that the account should have been closed, and the charge was invalid.I'm still waiting for them to call me with my $500+ refund, but instead, I received a notice from the collection agency for the money they couldn't charge me after the second attempted account closure. If this is not an example of extreme incompetence, I don't know what is. AT&T, get your act straight and give me my money back! Please!Update 1/3/24: Upgrading from 1 star to 3 stars. After multiple further unsuccessful engagements with AT&T customer support, I ended up initiating a dispute which prompted ATT Office of the President (top tier customer support) contacting me. Donato A. was able to help me and issue the refund as well as cancel the invalid debt collection. Thank you Donato!

When AT&T advertises a "Buy One-Get One" deal - buyer beware! NOTHING is free with AT&T!My BOGO deal was a "free" iPhone 7 when purchasing (signing a contract for) an iPhone 7+. After the purchase, I noticed a recurring credit of $21 on my bill. I thought it was because of certain discounts I get for membership in an organization AT&T honors, so I didn't pay much attention to the credit.Later, when I was able to pay off all my mobile devices, I noticed my bill had increased over $300! After arguing with the customer service rep, I was informed that AT&T had expected me to continue the installment payment plan for the iPhone 7+ for 30 months. But because I paid the balance for the installment plan after only 17 months, I was now liable for the remaining balance for the "BOGO" iPhone 7. I was INCREDULOUS!When I objected, the lady told me that I was informed this would happen at the time I paid off the balance. However I was never informed and told the customer service rep that if they wanted the $300 for the "free" phone they should take it out of the other rep's paycheck because he failed to inform me of the consequences of paying off the balance of the installment plan.Of course, she said they couldn't do that. So I demanded that AT&T should absorb the $300 because it's a misunderstanding and, after all, I've been a loyal customer for 25 years and it would be good customer relations. I said if AT&T would do this, I would make my satisfaction known publicly through Social Media. However, if AT&T failed to handle this in my favor, I said I would take that experience public on Social Media as well.The customer service rep paused for a moment, put me on hold, and voila! When she reconnected with me she said they had worked out a deal for me. If I "technically" put the iPhone 7 BACK on an "installment plan," they could continue the monthly $21 credit until the balance of the installment plan was paid, with nothing coming out of my pocket! I agreed to this compromise, and AT&T has held up their end of the bargain. So, AT&T is now paying for their own "free" BOGO phone again.This issue was, indeed, resolved to my satisfaction, and ALL of the 3 service reps I spoke with were courteous, friendly, and competent.But remember, AT&T + BOGO = Buyer Beware!! Nothing is "free" with AT&T.

iDMobile is good value for money - I think I have a very good deal.  But I have given it three stars because:1. The only way to contact anyone seems to be by chat.  When I had a problem with a direct debit (see below) I wasn't able to talk to anyone: the only telephone number I could find on you web site is for complaints.  So I had to use chat and my experience is that operators mostly seem to answer the question before the last one I asked, or answer a question I never asked.2. I changed the account from which the direct debit is taken.  I entered the details correctly and your web site accepted them.  The first I knew of a problem was when I received a text message telling me that immediate payment was required and that my account had been suspended.  To find out what had happened I had to first pay the monthly amount.  That was challenging because I logged into your website using my laptop, tried to pay and got the very uninformative error message of "Oops, something went wrong".  I ended up paying by phone.  I could then ring my bank and found out that iDMobile hadn't set up the direct debit properly - the money had been taken from my account but because the bank hadn't received the necessary notification about the direct debit, it was immediately returned to my account.  I opened a chat window to talk about it with you and for some reason failed the ID checks - I think my PIN didn't validate (and yes, I'm certain I typed it correctly; and I verified it was set to what I thought it was after the chat) so ended up having to submit a photocopy of my passport and utility bill to get your operator to communicate with me. The only saving grace was that this had happened when I was at home so was able to use my computer (which is not reliant on iDMobile) to research and sort things out.  It could have been very awkward had I been abroad.At the very least, given how long I've been a customer (nearly six years), you could have given me a few days warning before suspending the account. And yes, after all that, I did make use of the single telephone number on your site to make a complaint.

It used to be fine when I had a 3 contract (same phone) and then as expected OK with idMobile (MVO) for a few years. Now drops the call occasionally.>Reply from iD Mobile>An hour ago>>Hey there, we're very sorry to hear you're having >issues with coverage.>>Please take a look at our coverage checker, which will >show you what your signal strength should be like in >your area, for all of 3G/4G/5G, for both indoors and >outdoors.>.idmobile.co.uk/ help-and-advice/coverage#coverage-info>>Furthermore, please take a look at our network >partner Three's network status checker, which will >show if there is any maintenance or performance >upgrades going on in your area. If the website states >that's the case, then it's likely that this is disrupting >your coverage, and we hope that this is resolved soon >for you.>>https://www. three.co.uk /support/>network_and_coverage/network_support>>>Please take a look at both of these. If you believe you >should be experiencing better signal than you are, or >if the networks status checker on Three's website >isn't showing any upgrades or maintenance, then >please do email us on socialqueries at idmobile.co.uk >so we can look into this further for you.>>Kind regards,>TylerReplying to the reply by idmobile.:Yes I know all that. Of course I do. I was a telecoms software engineer for many years including mobile. The reason why the calls now drop out is because in this area, 3 have removed a number of older transmitters replacing them with fewer 4G/5G transmitters resulting in more fringe areas (grey spots) until they start to backfill. I live in a small market town close to a major new city and not some rural back area. A similar and well documented situation existed when t-mobile merged with Orange to become EE and EE removed far more duplicate transmitters that they should have done basing this on computer modelling coverage rather than actual real world coverage. OFCOM became involved and EE had to fix it.  Going back to idmobile and 3 , I am expecting (and hope) this call drop out problem to substantially reduce once 5G covers this area. Or more to the point, 3 commission the currently idle masts. Having said all that, I was a direct customer of 3 for many, many years but moved to idmobile roughly for the same price. Idmobile have a far superior and easy to use website, data-rollover, and inclusive international roaming covering much of the world that 3 used to cover. I have no intention of cancelling my idmobile contract.

The lady advised that I need to go to “Currys” as ID Mobile is a trade name for Currys, She advised to take a photographed ID so they can provide me with a Sim and activate the line with my old number. This looked too easy for me to believe, I had a copy of the chat emailed to me.As soon as I finished work, picked my passport and went to Currys, Exactly what I expected, David at Currys says: Sorry sir, this is very wrong information, I can only give you blank sim and you have to call them. Trying to explain that “There is no one to talk to and no number to help” did not add much to this waste of time conversation.Just to note, the chat service is only available until 18:00 then it gives you automated response.I went back home and fiddles online to find that I can simply do the porting on line via an authentication code that they will send to my mobile “That I do not have” !!Following some further search and frustration, I managed to get the code via my email I used to purchase the plan !During activation, it gave me at least 15 times message that “Something is wrong, try again”. Following 20 attempts, I got a different message that this sim card was previously activated !!Testing the sim card, It started working. HallelujahConclusion:ID Mobile has not trained its staff to know what are they managing or advisingID Mobile is sending important Sims after activation with untracked 2nd class Royal Mail! If someone gets hold of your mobile, may become able to get authentication codes for all your bank accounts..etc. Dangerous practice. Please use a safe tracked serviceID Mobile has a very poor customer service level as it is all on-line but very limited to probably one employee on the other side of the globe !For Customer:Do not port your number until you receive the Sim CardDo not try to communicate with ID Mobile, you will get frustrated and get no where.If you face my situation, Get a blank Sim from Currys, click, lost or damaged sim, for replacement, you will manage to do it online provided that you have registered with them your email.Conclusion:I will see how will the service go, I may buy again from them is phone and net service is satisfactory but I will be very careful to avoid similar situations and loosing my number for 10 days.

This review relates to the refer a friend scheme only, overall with the rest of the ID mobile,  I've had no problems.The refer a friend scheme seems designed to make sure you don't get the referral monies, unless you have the time and persistence. It starts well that you get a link to use to instigate the referral. Other companies then use this link to track and pay the bonus, but not ID mobile.The first step is the referred person needs to make contact to enter the  account number within 14 days. (Hurdle 1)Then you need to remember 90 days later that you referred someone as the money is not credited automatically. If you manage to remember then after a live chat your be told that the other person, either the referrer or referee needs to make contact first as well.  (Hurdle 2).The other person then makes contact and that seems to unlock some blocker on the referee account. (Hurdle 3).Then the referee has to make contact again to again request the bonus is paid (Hurdle 4).You are then told that for the other person to get their bonus they have to make contact again. (Hurdle 5).If you have read this review to this point - you are probably someone who might get the bonus, you have persistence!I queried the process and was sent terms and conditions of the scheme, it may say that you have to take all these steps (it just feels like they are there to thwart issuing the bonus), but in summary won't be referring anyone else - the process is just unnecessarily too time consuming and complicated.

I bought a new phone with a 24 month contract on iD Mobile on Black Friday. The SIM card doesn't work and when I try to register for an iD Mobile account online it says I have the incorrect details. I did this immediately and it took over 48 hours for them to reply that the details I gave them are incorrect or incomplete.  They asked for my iD Mobile customer PIN which I do not know because I cannot register for an online account and the name of my bank. I am still waiting for a response.I am concerned about my personal data and have reservations about using a company that can make such a big mistake without offering adequate customer service.  I'm now stuck paying for a SIM  card I cannot use on a contract that I cannot cancel! I  am also worried about how iD Mobile is handling my  personal data as this appears to be a pretty big breach.At this point I wouldn't recommend iD Mobile to anybody, from my experience the lower prices donot make up for the hassle and the stress.Update (15/12/2023): This issue has now finally been resolved by the Carphone Warehouse and iD Mobile. It has been a stressful couple of weeks and I feel that no customer should have to deal with the problems I have encountered, especially when the original issue was caused through no fault of my own.  I feel there is a lesson to be learned here for the Carphone Warehouse and iD Mobile that communication between the two companies needs to be improved.Having said that, I would hope that the issue that I encountered was out of the ordinary and eventually I did manage to contact representatives from the Carphone Warehouse and iD Mobile that were able to help me and provided a level of customer service that I would expect from a big company.  It's just a shame that this didn't happen in the first place.

My overall experience with O2 has been mixed. There is no other way to describe it.Let's start off with the positives.I have what I would call an unbeatable deal from O2 thanks to the Virgin Mobile migration. My phone bill is £6.79/mo for completely unlimited data (on VM, it was for 2GB, plan price was originally 2GB for a 12 month contract in 08/2018), which no other network would ever be able to beat. I currently use around 40GB in a month, which is a stark contrast to never using over 4GB in a month for 5 years. Granted my usage habits have changed now that I'm free to burn my data.Through the Virgin Mobile migration, I also gained the ability to use 4G calling and WiFi calling (yes Virgin did have the ability for both, but it just would have been a pain to set up) from the moment I migrated. Unfortunately, these features did disappear for a long time (from about July to mid-December) which sucks. I don't make calls often but both options make calls crystal clear and reliable.A bit after mid-November, I decided to get a SIM swap with O2, since I was still using my old Virgin SIM (which was originally programmed to connect to the EE network, still have remnants of that even with my new O2 SIM with the T-Mobile MNC seemingly reporting "Virgin Mobile" when manually searching for networks). The SIM swap processed extremely quickly with being delivered within just 2 days (one day after my order confirmation), which was a stark contrast from the experience that I had with moving someone from Plusnet to EE (SIM took 4 days to deliver and EE didn't even send confirmation details).Priority is a cool plus to have and getting Volt features is nice too.Now the negatives.With the migration, I was promised the visual voicemail feature on my Android phone, but it has yet to work for me. I've had a tab for it appear once, but that's it.On Virgin, RCS always worked perfectly fine. Meanwhile on O2, I've had a few problems (particularly by the migration from O2's RCS to Jibe RCS) and it's left me unable to use RCS.I'd like to finally end this off with a concern I have for the future as an O2 customer. Due to the way that O2 migrated Virgin customers, my tariff price is £13.29 with a £6.50 discount bolt-on. I am concerned that the annual price increases will cost more on O2 than it would of on Virgin due to the way that the migration was handled.

As of the time of writing this review, one of our contracts has been canceled, and we're hoping it stays that way. Prior to this, my family had three contracts: one for myself, one for my dad, and one for my little brother. My dad and I had a generally positive experience with our contracts, with only occasional internet signal issues, which were infrequent and didn't significantly affect our overall satisfaction.Now, let's delve into the canceled contract concerning my little brother. Approximately two months ago, he temporarily lost his phone, but he managed to retrieve it the following day. On the day the phone was lost, we promptly contacted the service provider to report it and have the number barred. We were informed that we'd need to wait for 24 hours for the bar to be lifted, which we accepted. However, for the following three days, my brother couldn't make calls or use data. We reached out to customer support, only to be advised that switching SIM cards would be quicker. We visited the first store in Wembley, but my brother failed to answer the security questions and lacked the required identification, which, understandably, the store couldn't overlook.We then tried another store in Edgware while I was taking care of my car. We brought two forms of ID and proof of billing, and requested a new SIM card. However, we faced the same issue with security questions and ID verification. The system seemed to have a glitch in specifying which security question to answer. We contacted the service provider, and it turned out that my brother had two security questions and answers, and the system wasn't clear on which one to use. Despite answering correctly, the issue persisted.After trying to resolve the problem for several days, including obtaining multiple SIM cards and switching to different phones, we realized the problem wasn't with the SIM but likely linked to my brother's account. The service provider promised to investigate, but after a week, they requested another week to continue their inquiry. Keep in mind that we made repeated calls during this process, and sometimes the support team didn't have the necessary information, forcing us to provide it repeatedly.After waiting for over a month and a half with no resolution in sight, we decided to cancel the contract. Fortunately, we were given credit, so we didn't have to pay, but it became apparent that having a contract was pointless if we couldn't use the SIM. Interestingly, we switched to Giffgaff, which operates on the same network as our previous provider (O2), using the PAC code for our number, and everything worked perfectly. As such, I don't expect a cancellation bill, as I left the contract due to the absence of service, which should be evident in their records. It appears that my account was disabled at the time of writing this review.

I have switched back to EE, and back to the normal 50-60mbps 4G speeds.Their customer service team, particularly the technical support team aren't very good they told me that their phone masts were working correctly and that the network might be "busy" and when I complained regarding the slow speeds they made no effort to retain me as a customer and the retentions team processed my cancelation within minutes. Maybe they are aware of the slow speeds?To me, 4G speeds should be at a minimum of 30mbps, and just like home broadband packages now they should be regulated with a minimum guaranteed speed at your home address. I was lucky in this instance that O2 allow you to pay off your device and leave, but if it was over the 14 day cooling off period and I was with another provider then I would have been stuck in a 24 month contract with slow speeds. Hats off to O2 for resolving my issue and allowing me to leave my contract, I would return as a customer if they sort out the speed of their 4G services.

I don't know where to start. We've seen the worst possible customer service with over 8 hours on the phone to O2 in more than 30 calls. Their phone was not on O2.- After much wrangling and refusals, O2 replaced the O2 contract handset with a new one via next day delivery but denied any responsibility for the £1,100 + non O2 Iphone 12 Pro they had made unusable. The formal complaint process was initiated via email. After sending screen shots directly whilst on the call via email to them, a new un-locked Iphone 12 Pro at zero cost was promised via next day delivery. I have had T-Mobile 5G Home Internet for 11 months. It was traumatic to install and took many hours. The Gateway is a small corded box controlled by a mobile based app, just plug the box in and turn on. My T-Mobile tower is 1/2 mile from my house, my Gateway sits next to a window about 10-30 feet from my devices, a MacAir book, 3 ipads, 2 iphones, an Epson printer USB connected to the Air book, and an LG smart tv. The advertised download speed is true, between 100-400 bps.The app, once the complicated passwords are renamed, is easy to use.My connection shows 'Excellent' about 95% of the time. I assume that means the connection between the box and the tower. The connection between the devices and the gateway are sporadic. Two of the ipads, uncorded, disconnect at least five times during the day, the worst is the lost connection to the 'Air Printer' several times a week. What is strange the one ipad and the tv are 100% corded and never lose connection. I suspect sharing the tower with the T-Mobile cellphone users may be part of the problem. My few calls to customer service were helpful and quick. I have paperless auto pay and is no problem. I have not disconnected the gateway and moved it to another location in the town, so can't say how that would work out. I recommend the service, which has limited locations, for the convenience, price, and listed speed, Maybe you would not experience the disconnect problems I have, a nuisance, but easily fixed by 'forgetting the network' and reconnecting with the password, There is no contract so a tryout will be easy to give up if not satisfied.

TMobile vs Straight talkSo not to long ago I switched from straight talk to TMobile. I expected to have a better overall plan, reasonably priced, and to have faster LTE speeds. About a month into using TMobile I have really not noticed a change, in fact the speeds were anything but fast. I have lost service all together many times,it has reverted back to 3G a few times, more often then straight ever did. Their 4G must not have much coverage or something and lacks the performance I would expect from a higher end phone company. I compared it to my straight talk account (it's still active because the plan was paid for when I switched)  and I did a speed test for mps. Straight talk speeds were significantly higher compared to TMobile. In fact they were double the speed. I wanted to compare playing a 1080p video running on just mobile data. TMobile had a hard time loading the video as it buffered several time throughout the video. While straight talk on the other hand had no problems playing the high frame rated video,it didn't buffer or cut out once. Now as far as plans go, I  am on TMobile one plus, Supposedly I get 2x higher speed LTE over the other plans. Now it is a great deal or all it offers,10mps in flight LTE, I can text and what not in other countries, and and if I add another line they pay for Netflix.  But the plan is only $75 and I pay $90. What are the $15 in fees for? What are the fees? Straight talk offers unlimited high speed LTE, talk and text for only $55 and only has about $5 in fees. Ithink it's safe to say (for me anyway) TMobile still has a ways to go before their service is better. I think I'll stick with straight talk for the moment.

Honestly, T-Mobile has been a great service ever since I switched over to them from Sprint but their "360 Protection" plan is an absolute scam and complete waste of money. I was paying $13 a month for a year a half after after I broke my previous phone and figured why not get insurance so the process is simpler and I can avoid having to pay full price again for a new phone. My current phone finally breaks and I find out that my $350 phone (now not even worth $120 brand new) won't be replaced without paying a $100 deductible. I could understand $100 maybe if I had a flagship phone but this was just insane considering I found my phone refurbished and like new selling online for around the same price.Long story short, do NOT get the phone insurance unless maybe you have a really expensive phone, and even still, I can see them still charging a ridiculous deductible that almost negates having the insurance to begin with. I mean, even with my middle range phone the deductible was more than it cost to just get another phone online. So yeah, do the math, $13 x 18 months = $234 that could have bought me the brand new version of my current phone where T-Mobile is simply giving me a pre-owned refurbished phone and STILL charging me $100 for the replacement, so really, it's costing me $324 to get a crumby replacement when I could easily buy an even better phone than my current one, brand new.So yeah, I give T-Mobile 3 stars because I love everything else about them but their insurance is just an awful scam. Too many hoops to jump through and then they'll still charge you through the nose just to get an even worse version (refurbished) of your current phone. Assurant is the company they use for their phone insurance. I know my rage should be focused solely on Assurant, but T-Mobile did decide to use them, so they still get a lot of the blame.

Update:  hurray!!!  T-Mobile credited our mobile account $784.94!I posted a story on the company’s FB page with hashtag TMobile and their customer service page and my FB page.  This detailed the facts on our reward and how we did not receive what was promised on the Bring Your Own Device promotion this last Fall (which is a current program too).After waiting over the requisite month for the reward payment and reaching out to Tmobile multiple times I was repeatedly and firmly denied by customer service at all levels in all departments.Having had enough frustration with “customer service” I reached out to the BBB and the FCC and was at the point of contacting our State’s Attorney General.I might note too that I did get an immediate response from the Tmobile T-force team when I hashtagged TMobile on their Facebook page, my FB page and the Tmobile customer feedback page. After lengthy messaging (don’t give up on that thread of communication) the T-force folks promised to try another claim and offer a full credit as a last resort in 2 weeks (which was today).I highly encourage anyone who gets shut down by Tmobile when you file your claim for reward to not give up. Hit them from the social media side and/or the offical complaint side with BBB.I was thrilled to get what was promised and look forward to a better relationship with TMobile.Don’t give up!  And let me know if you need encouragement in your attempt.Here’s the original story:We have been customers with another cellular service for nearly 20 years.  There are 4 phone users in my family.  We made the bold move to “bring your phone” to #T-Mobile and paid off 2 of our remaining contracts and were promised we would receive up to $800 for the move to T-Mobile.  Before crossing over to the new network we sent in our screenshots to T-Mobile and filled out the paperwork.  We were advised we would need to wait 6-8 weeks for the credit from T-Mobile.  After waiting for 3 months we called customer service and were told our paperwork was never filed and that we were past the one month deadline to re file our paperwork to receive our promotional amount.  When we were transferred to the promotional dept they said the same and that customer service would “escalate” this case and contact us.  No contact.  We called customer service in another week or two and were now told that the 2 month deadline had elapsed 5 days before our follow up call and that nothing could be done since we missed the deadline.  All this to say that we filed everything the day T-Mobile got 4 new customers to sign up with them.  They did not send us any of what we were promised, denied receiving our paperwork, told us we only had one month to file the paperwork, then told us they had extended that deadline to 3 months, and then told us that we did not meet any of their deadlines even with repeated calls to their reward dept and their customer service department.  I spent over a 6 hours speaking with representatives at T-Mobile feeling like I had when I was with AT&T.  I had hoped we were not dealing with another corporate company who just shuffled us around, but I soon learned T-Mobile was treating us the same way: with little regard for us as long term customers paying monthly.  We did nothing wrong on our end.  Is this the way a phone service treats its newest LONG term customers?  I will tell everyone our story when they say that T-Mobile is making promises to get new customers!  This might help you consider too what phone company you would like to pay monthly for multiple years.

I have been a Sprint customer for 16 years and recently became notified via text message that I had to acquire a T-Mobile SIM card as they have merged. The options were to have the card shipped to me for $10 or to go to a store. I chose to go to a store to avoid the shipping costs and reduce the possibility of error. The closest store is about 30-40 miles from my home. I went to the store and was given the SIM to take home. The woman in the store told me how to do it and told me where to go to watch a video on the process. I asked her to do it for me, she would not, so I went home and watched the video to do it myself. **In small writing on one insert in the SIM card box, it states that you need to back up your voicemails or you will lose them. It does not say this in the video, and the woman in the store did not tell me. I did not notice and I lost all of my voicemails. That is not the purpose of my review though.** I put the SIM in my phone exactly as instructed, and my phone no longer worked. It would not connect to wifi. It would not connect to service. It was a locked and useless piece of technology. I used my landline phone to call customer service. I remained calm and tried to work with the agents to restore the use of my iPhone. The first agent attempted to assist me for 6 minutes before disconnecting me. I called back and got another agent that was especially kind. She attempted to help me for about 25 minutes before determining that she would not be able to assist me because I did not have a way to receive the one time code that she needed to send me in order to verify my account, and apparently my SIM card was faulty/did not exist. Because my phone didn't work, there was no way to receive the code to dive further in to this issue. We eventually found a way for me to receive the code, which was done by me emailing my mom from my laptop to ask her to receive the code and send it to me via email. She put me on hold to discuss with her team and then transferred me to another agent without telling me she was doing so. The new agent was not briefed on the situation so I got him caught up to speed and he attempted to help me for about 55 minutes, in the process, he guided me through phone resets that were unsuccessful in restoring the use of my phone, but they were successful in removing every setting, password, and face ID that were in my phone. He did not tell me that that would happen. At the time, I was just wanting to restore the use of my phone and wasn't even focused on the extent of what I had just lost. He disconnected me without warning. I called back and was connected with an agent that simply informed me that there was no way to help me and that I needed to travel back to a T-Mobile store and then disconnected me. I called back and was connected to an agent that assisted me for 47 minutes, ultimately resolving the initial problem and getting my phone activated to T-Mobile service. He also offered to send me a booster at no cost to increase service in my home. He discovered that there is only one T-Mobile tower in my area (there were 7 Spring towers) and that my service would be poorly effected by this switch. I was grateful for his help and his willingness to go above and beyond to help me with issues beyond what I was calling for. He was not able to help me restore my voicemails or my lost passwords/other information, but that is certainly not his fault. Every agent was pleasant, I had no personal issues with any of them, but they were not able/willing to help me and didn't seem to really care about the situation I was in. He thanked me for staying calm and kind and acknowledged how frustrated I must have felt. I would like to rate my last agent, Christian, every star in the world, because without him, T-Mobile would have lost a 16 year customer yesterday. I spent many hours of my day trying to do what they asked of me - not something I ever wanted - and it was a major inconvenience that caused a lot of stress. As far as I can tell, the only thing T-Mobile has done right is hire Christian. He deserves a lot of praise, and a raise. Christian, if you see this - please know how grateful I am. That is all, thanks.

I've had TMobile for 14 years and have seen them improve greatly in the last 6 of those. I've always lived in an urban/suburban area and have had solid signal with very good coverage and data speeds. The LTE speeds in the 3-4 years have been excellent. Their customer service approach (teams with regional focus and follow-up to resolution) is far better than the past, and I had no reason to believe that would change according to inner reports from friends who are employees.In September of 2017 I noticed a drastic change in customer service policy/procedure - more calls to 611 than in the past were routed to overseas call centers who 1) had little ability/authority to resolve matters 2) struggled with the English language in their communication 3) couldn't relate to social and practical issues like addresses that directly affect US customers - all of which became more of a 'reading off a script' experience and endless cyclical talking that went nowhere.   In addition, any Twitter support through DirectMessaging was focused on hyper positivity, lofty rhetoric, exaggerated claims of expertise, and writing too much about themselves in an attempt to sympathize and empathize in obvious relatability - all which would be fine if accompanied with competence, accuracy, attention to detail, follow through, and a timely resolution. Because of these changes in customer service approach/policy, issues that formerly took days to a week to resolve now become lingering problems that last weeks to a month or more.I moved to a suburban/rural area that is still within a couple miles of a larger city, and according to antenna search/locator sites and an app called Network Cell Info Lite, there are several T-Mobile towers in my area, from 1/2 to 4 miles away with only one obstructed by geography (foothill). I never connect to the closest 4G tower, leading me to believe it's inactive or non-functioning. Doing drive tests with the diagnostic app reveal a very weak signal being br oadcast by most of the towers in the area, and even with full signal reception on phone (bars) the latency is very bad and data speeds are horrible and subpar - more akin to that of 3G or less.All of this information has been passed and communicated to TMobile over the past 4 weeks with little more than 'there are geographical difficulties' being reported from the engineers in the field.  This is only true of 1 out of the 6+ towers in the area.  I understand business decisions of cost vs benefit, and that unless/until a large customer base was complaining of problems they would delay or refrain from addressing such issues, but it seems there exists a lack of maintenance and ongoing upgrade concern/competence.  All the happy-talk virtue signaling in the world from customer service reps doesn't alter that.So I'm now experiencing what many others in 'less than adequate' coverage areas have experienced and the apparent changes in customer support have only exacerbated the frustration and unacceptable conditions.  This is my 2Cents.You can't trust their coverage map claims which are misleading, false, and blatantly full of errors.However, if you live in an area where towers are maintained and the signal is strong, their service is one of the best.  They really need to think through and work on their customer service approach - once again.**UPDATE 11/07/2017**After multiple attempts to contact a customer care or technical support person within the US by phone, I got lucky and reached a first level tech support person who transferred me to the 2nd level support. They took extensive notes and then created a ticket to be sent to engineers - meanwhile I created such an uproar on public Twitter messages that I was contacted by DirectMessage and they requested to call me directly to resolve the problem.During all of this, I continued to search for answers/solutions online. None of the support personnel directed or linked me to any T-Mobile online support documentation - but in my searches I found what I thought might be the problem. There was a detailed T-Mobile support document that did indeed provide some helpful information and could've been forwarded or linked or sent to me within the first day or two.Solution? The Personal Cellspot 4G LTE mini tower needed a complete 'reset', which can be accomplished by holding down the reset button on the back of the mini tower for 20+ seconds.  Up to this point, I had only tried 10 and 15 seconds as well as unplugging it for 30 minutes.  Once I did the 20+ second reset, the data speeds returned to a normal level (80-90mbits down, 30-45mbits up) and all was well.  I relayed all of this information - including the support documentation URL to T-Mobile support teams on Twitter and phone support and hopefully they will begin a process of searching for 'known issues' and FAQ's while assisting customers in order to actually resolve issues and to learn themselves in the process.

Although my contract is with Vodafone,  I’ve posted this review for them (3 stars) and 2 stars for City Fibre.During the 13 months as a customer of City Fibre with Vodafone providing the broadband, there have been 2 periods of total loss of service (outages). Recent outage for 4 full days; previously 2 days.Regarding the latter 4 days loss of service:Negatives• Having a family member dependent on broadband for homeworking has meant extra costs, travel elsewhere, and a lot of stress and frustration.• 4 days to fix the problem seems excessive.• Very difficult to get a direct answer regarding the exact cause of the problem – no direct communication with City Fibre permitted.  I was informed by Vodafone that the line was damaged and needed replacing. Knowing the cause [of the damage] is important in assessing if this might be a recurring event.• Vodafone has limitations on Ofcom’s automatic compensation scheme, i.e. no payments for the first 48 hours of loss of service.• Vodafone appear overly reliant on City Fibre with little influence regarding obtaining detailed communication, such as in this situation.• City Fibre’s website claims of a reliable and consistent service, is debatable. It is a subjective experience, and mine has been mixed; it has been made worse by no clear explanation of the cause of the disruption.Positives:• Vodafone did what it could in terms of communication, which was generally good and respectful, but ultimately they were reliant on information from City Fibre.• Vodafone has signed up to Ofcom’s automatic compensation scheme.• When the broadband is running, it is generally working well.It seems to me some things happen that are outside anybody’s control, as may be the case in these outages. This doesn’t help in the frustration and disruption caused to those that rely on the service. However, a quicker fix of the problem and some clearer communication would certainly have helped.

Vodafone currently supply our home broadband - I believe many of the issues with broadband stem from BT OpenReach one way or another, but Vodafone is a big enough company in it's own right to take some responsibility/not be bullied too much.Set up was a bit of a shambles - told the line needed installing even though the new-build house already had an active fibre connection with lights on(!) Waited an extra month or so just for a guy from OpenReach to come in and say 'yup that's fine' and leave.Connection is ok, has been a little flaky sometimes but generally fine for daily work and evening media streaming. On the occasion it drops though, router can take a very long time to regain a lost connection. Router is mediocre and app control is terrible... if you ever manage to set it up to your phone it chucks you out permanently at some point, and to reconnect the app you need to reset the router completely (even that didn't always work). Gave up on it.Again - OpenReach and many customer-facing telecom suppliers are doing it, but mid-contract, (over) inflationary rises in price is a dodgy practice in my eyes, however many companies there are that do it. If I sign up to a £30, 24 month contract I should be paying £30 in month 23, not ~£40. Else don't call it a contract - let customers leave whenever you change the terms (price).In all, absolutely no reason to stay at end of contract so will look to ditch and switch - as many services force you to nowadays - unless you want to sit paying more than you need to for being loyal/'lazy'.

I've been with voda for many years . Over that time I've varied my plan according to business and social needs and its worked well. Staff you contact are usually very helpful and their customer service system works well. Travelling the world their data and telephony connections were usually reliable and high quality.However when it comes to the hard core subject of cash they let themselves down very badly in several areas .Firstly they were very fast to remove automatic covered  roaming post brexit but even before that they were clamping down and becoming inflexible. They introduced a system whereby if you were out of the uk got a certain time your  roaming cost you extra even on an inclusive plan. It was a complicated calculation that they got wrong and started charging me a month early and would not back down for quite some time and did so just before the regulator was about to step in.We then move onto in plan price rises . Fair enough up the cost by the RPI , though it is a bit of a money gtab, but then to add a further 3 point something percent on for "network investment" ?? Surely ongoing investment is par to operating and development strategy and accommodated within the overall business plan ?Someone somewhere is being greedy and then shoots themselves in the foot by posting massive profits .To put all of that in context I have an EU plan too . Unlimited texts and sms . 8gb of data ( chosen by me) with EU and UK roaming . All for €9.99 with excellent service. Voda can't or won't  come anywhere near that.Update : whilst voda prices are on the up again my provider has put me on unlimited everything for the equivalent of Uk £10, still with roamimg. Voda are poor value.Goodbye voda.

Taken out a 2 year Broadband Service 500Mbs, changing over from BT 100Mbs service. Took about around half a day for the service to start but the VOIP transfer of the phone number from BT took somewhat longer. That doesn't surprise me and I wouldn't jump to conclusions the extra delay in down to Vodafone. Getting a mobile number transferred between operators  generally goes much more smoothly than transfer of landline numbers. I think it's a good deal at least for the contact period, even factoring in the ubiquitous April over inflation price increases that everyone applies.But whilst my phone number is now recognized the phone still doesn't work as they forgot to include a VOIP phone adapter in the equipment they sent me so they are having to now send through a  BS 6312 (BT) female to RJ11 male adapter separately. The order did include wired phone service  so I'm uncertain whether this omission was a mistake OR if they are just trying to penny pinch by excluding the adapter from the package. It's probably not a great idea to let people try to source their own VOIP adaptor, because there are various types with/without low pass filter and with/without ringing capacitor, and use of the wrong type could then lead to further issues.They did send superfluous adaptors for DSL which I don't need as I'm on Optical Fibre now and don't actually have a copper line any longer. In general I think they could save a bit of cost AND give a better service by matching up the equipment they send with the equipment needed for the order.The telephone  support for this problem was OK, but the link they sent via SMS for video call setup (so they could look at the connections on the back of the router) didn't work so well as the web page on the link  wouldn't let me grant permissions to use my smart phone camera whilst the ongoing phone call icon was still on screen in the foreground. So I had to drop the phone call first in order to grant permissions, and was then me on a video call for where I couldn't hear/see any one on the other end. It did the job though and I left the camera pointing at the back of the router and it became clear later that they had seen what they needed to see when they called me back (though the security questions all needed going through again). I've certainly had a lot worse support from other ISPs and was straight through to someone without waiting when I called them.The router they sent is a Technicolor THG3000. Comparable specs to the Sagecom built BT Smart Hub2 that I was using previously. Slightly more intuitive web user interface, I think. But still no 802.11ax (WiFi 6) or WPA3 security option. Would be nice to see movement from WiFi 5 as some operators are now gearing up to roll out routers with WiFi 7. I was hoping for a WiFi 6 based router, but not too surprised that I didn't get one.Update: The VoIP adapter arrived, but it still didn't have a ringing capacitor within it so everything worked apart from my phone not actually ringing when it's receiving a call. However I know the superfluous DSL filter I was sent will have a 1.0 - 1.8 uF capacitance across the 2 wire voice line side. So I connect the VOIP adapter to the router, the DSL filter to the VOIP adapter, and the phone to the voice side of the DSL filter and BINGO the phone now rings. Nothing like the diagram I was sent but it works. I have the advantage of having worked for GEC Plessey Telecoms in the past so I understood what a non ringing phone means and how to fix that. I fear that Vodafone don't understand any of it anymore because everything is outsourced in such a way that the left hand no longer knows what the right is doing and there is less and less technical expertise actually left in the company itself.

Wow, I see that a lot of people are not happy with the price hikes. 10.5% CPI, 3.9% towards rolling out full fibre to more homes. I'm not even a full fibre customer so I will be paying this added cost so others receive a faster service. So in total, a 14.4% increase to me mid contract.Originally when I joined Vodafone, I was paying about £19 a month for 55Mbs, with the latest increase, its closer to £26.The price of my current plan is actually closer to what people are paying for full fibre, 500Mbs symmetrical download/upload. This means less value for me.I still have over a year of my contract left with Vodafone but it actually worked out cheaper for me to cancel it anyway and pay the cancellation fee.The cancellation fee is based on money that you would have paid Vodafone minus the costs that Vodafone have to pay as a result of you, being their customer. By this, I mean, they deduct tax, deduct line rental for however many months and then recalculate the tax based on the new amount.This meant that the cancellation fee for the remaining year of contract was about £82.I then found a company called Lit that would do me full fibre, 500Mbs download, 500Mbs upload for £27 a month.Based on me still being in a contract with Vodafone, they also offered me 6 months free service to cover the cost of my cancellation fee. They have also promised me that there will not be any mid contract price hikes.This means that I now have a new 24 month contract with the first 6 months free, followed by 18 payments of exactly £27. Total for 24 months, including cancellation fee is £568.Vodafone said they had a better deal as I wouldn't have to pay the cancellation fee and I wouldn't have to pay the 14.4% this April if I took out a new contract.They offered me 500Mbs download (250Mbs guaranteed) 68Mbs upload for £30 a month. Taking into consideration that CPI will be added April 2024, I estimated that my bill would increase to £35 a month for approximately 12 months. In total, it would have costed me £780 to take another 24 month contract with Vodafone.I explained the numbers to the Vodafone advisor who still insisted that their deal was some how better. A lot of attention was focused on the cancellation fee that obviously I had already allowed for and factored in when comparing what was on offer.The advisor then proceeded to try and discredit Lit, saying they have never heard of them. I forwarded a link to their website. The advisor then said there wasn't any reviews, so I forwarded them a link to trustpilot where Lit score 4.9 out of 5. The advisor said that they didn't think I would get 6 months for free and to be careful incase it's a scam. They then said that the 6 months free is probably offered because they are a business that knows its going under. I explained it was to compensate people for the cancellation fee when switching mid contract. He then said that my contract will definitely still go up with Lit as all companies have to increase contracts based on CPI. I had to send a screenshot to the advisor to prove that Lit do not hike prices mid contract. This is also true for companies like Tescos mobile who also don't increase their prices.I feel like a lot of what I was being told wasn't strictly correct, so do be careful what you believe. The chat also went on for several hours despite me originally only contacting Vodafone to give my 30 days notice.I am, however, still suprised that Vodafone have a rating of 1.3 out of 5 on here. Despite my moan above, my service with Vodafone has been fantastic over the years that I've been with them. My speeds were always where they should have been and the service was very reliable with next to no drop outs. If there ever was a problem, Vodafone were quick to get it resolved.The low rating on here is quite harsh and not really a true reflection of them as a company. I would definitely consider moving back to Vodafone in the future if they have a good deal on.Unfortunately, being loyal to one company doesn't really work in the consumers favour and quite often results in prices continually increasing the longer you stay with them. As consumers, it is up to us to shop around for the best deals.

My husband says the internet is slow (we have the super fast fibre) and prefers to use his mobile data but I honestly do not notice the speed being slow, maybe because he doesn’t use it relieving the pressure of demand? All in all I would probably recommend Vodafone broadband. At the moment we are out of contract so our monthly payment is more than if we were in contract, I haven’t renewed a contract as I like the fact that I have the option to just leave if I want to, but so far I haven’t needed to. Eventually customer service sorted my issue, but before that it was a merry go round of speaking to different departments.My contract with Vodafone transferred to me in the middle of the month. I'd been with them for over a decade and never had problems. I'm on a plan with 25GB data per month. Then suddenly, two days into August, I get a text saying I had only 2GB worth of data left. Which made no sense as I was constantly using wifi at home and I work from home.The first person I spoke to said it was a glitch and that she would renew my data amount. Nothing happened.The second person said it was the 'transition period' of the contract transition, and that it would renew properly on the 8th of August, today. Nothing happened.On my third call, I spoke to someone who knew what they were doing and did a deep dig into my daily data use and summarised that I had used 9GB instead of 22GB when travelling the prior week, which made sense. However a colleague then told her that the day-by-day data wasn't accurate and that 22GB was correct, which also made no sense. He wasn't helpful, and reiterated it was on my end and not theirs.Under family advice I called up Retentions threatening to leave and got an extra 2GB for free as a good will gesture. Doesn't explain where 13GB went, but it's better than nothing.I will be doing better research into other providers next year as a back-up.

June 2022:The Vodafone network has been down in postcode SK13 5DP for nearly 3 weeks. I received a text saying maintenance complete but the Vodafone network is still down in this area. There have been problems for 3 weeks now and no one at Vodafone seems to know what the problem is or when it will be fixed. Even their website shows the network is down. This is a rural area and people rely on their phones to keep in touch. Total shambles.July 17th 2022:After some investigation I have discovered that at the end of June 2022 Vodafone upgraded my local mast as part of maintenance program in preparation for 5G. The upgrade failed and the mast shutdown. My device then  connected to another mast further away greatly reducing my service (2 bars from 5 bars). The Vodafone website stated there was a fault for a few days and then said service was back to normal which it wasn't. After a coupe of weeks my service has improved and I am getting excellent down /upload speeds so it seems to have been fixed. Vodafone clearly had a problem and I just wish they would have been honest. Their contact centre and the TOBI app just lied to me or disconnected me when I tried to investigate the problem. Vodafone have provided me with good mobile service over the years but they really need to improve their contact centers who do not seem to have a clue when their is a major network outage.I have increased my rating as I am now getting excellent speeds. People on the Vodafone Forum were very helpful.

Today after 7 and a half years, I received my PAC code from Vodafone. I'm not going to write a dramatic 1 star review. My signal with Vodafone is generally strong and I've had no issues with customer services. But this company has consumer ethics problems.However, since COVID, the signal has not been as strong. I used to be the only person in my group of friends who used to get a signal at the football and now I'm not, it's as bad as the rest. So when I get e-mails telling me my prices are going up because of the cost of living, I expect to see my service being excellent. But unfortunately it went backwards.My bill has gone up and up and the cost of living raise was, I'm afraid, unfair, exploitative and the final straw and the reason I am leaving today. This is from the e-mail in March:"The monthly cost of your plan will go up from your April 2022 bill. As set out in the terms of your agreement with us, this increase is the UK Consumer Price Index (CPI) rate of 5.4% (as published in January 2022) to support the rise in our running costs and keep up with increased demand, plus an additional 3.9% to continue essential investment in our network as we expand coverage."This is frankly predatory and I will not support it. So I am off to Lebara - they use the Vodafone network and will charge me about a quarter of what I currently pay with a superior deal. I am sad to be leaving, I have been with Vodafone for the best part of 8 years. But the SIM only tariffs are no longer competitive, there was no real effort to keep my custom (not that I was ever going to stay) and I cannot emphasise enough how much I dislike that 3.9% rise. My coverage has got worse, not better, so previous rises are obviously not being spent wisely.In terms of coverage and overall experience, I have had few issues with Vodafone. In fact, they're pretty good. But the time has come to seek cheaper pastures elsewhere because a 9.3% rise when cost of living is out of control is predatory, exploitative and downright unfair.So you will get good coverage and friendly customer service experience, but you will pay for it and it will be outside of the amount you agreed to pay every month.Goodbye Vodafone. It's been fun.

A bit painful overall unfortunately, but the customer staff were as great as they could be.Saw a great offer online in March for Samsung S21 5G, Unlimited Max plan. With a guaranteed trade in of my S10e (subject to meeting conditions), £44 per month (24 months). Great deal!Placed order Wed 31 Mar after 10.00pm, so too late for next day delivery. Fine. It's Easter weekend so can wait until the following Tues.Received email confirmation 22.31 for delivery on Tues 6 Apr. Nothing delivered.On inquiring, response was that the order was cancelled due to a 'technical issue'. No reason for error given, or why no follow up email to tell me. Passed around from initial complaints to upgrades to customer care, back to upgrades, etc.... Upshot - I can upgrade but only at today's (7 Apr) rates (which, shock, are not as generous); not the one I thought I signed up to (when I got my last phone, the following month the plan price went down. I had no recourse to ask for a better rate though...)Small print online states the contract only applies 'when the product is dispatched'. Not when you click that button to purchase. Not when you get the confirmation email. Not when you get it in your grubby little mitts. But only when dispatched. As such, it appears that if the courier loses it, or it is delayed... you are still liable to pay the prevailing rate (until found or proved stolen, I assume). If the order is cancelled by Vodafone (for any one of a number of reasons - or none, just a 'technical error'...), unlucky, no contract stands. The risk is transferred to you, my friends. Tell me I am wrong, Vodafone. Then I will show you your own terms and conditions.If you order online, get a confirmation and take a day off and get no email to say it is cancelled. Unlucky as no contract. And you cannot then ask for the original terms to be honoured as the 'deal is no longer available'. Those good old T&C.What was good was the attitude of all the customer support staff I engaged with. They got it. They listened. They were obviously limited by company policy. After putting in a formal (email) written complaint since the phone system just wasn't working, I got a response very quickly and the guy was great. The key thing was the confirmation email I received, that proved I had made the order - it was the only evidence as 'nothing was in the system' (don't delete those emails, folks). Complaint upheld in terms of cancellation made without my knowledge and no confirmatory email sent to me. Nonetheless, the 'technical issue' won through and those pesky terms and conditions (weighted in favour of the company) won out. Legally right; morally...?I have to comment I did go ahead with an upgrade, after being offered 25% discount on another monthly plan; it would be wrong not to disclose this. The deal was decent but not anywhere near as good as that which I thought I had committed to.In short. Customer service were actually really decent and I truly appreciate their attempts to help. But the company-level T&C element leaves the customer in a weak position if things go wrong. You takes your chance folks!

Latest Review (three-and-a-half stars)The company answered my questions forthrightly over the phone and also put the price down from what it was, which was a nice surprise, the service now being (substantially more) worth the monthly cost.Technical-wise, the internet has been impressive, able as we are now, to stream without interference, the BBC at best-quality, sometimes, and (not a fan of...) Amazon Prime at best-quality.Am hoping to implement call-forwarding, in attempts to try out different routes for connection, and if everything goes as well as it currently does, am thinking it might work.No reason to change company as-of-yet and am pleased to have stuck around for the long-haul.The deficit in the star-rating is the issue of mobile-phone protocols: on 3G-only phones, you cannot be on the internet and a call at the same time (why I am trying call-divert), which does not allow for the fact that some people use older phones.Older Review (company had two stars)In trying to think of positive things to say about the public sector and PLCs and communication companies of the private sector, have found it immensely difficult.This particular mini-dictatorship does at least provide fast enough speeds behind the hype. And as such, am able to stream live-TV using Mobile Hotspotting.However, those who take up the helm in the handling of customer queries (in particular, those higher up the ladder-of-ambition, snugly buckled into their Imperial Fleet seating arrangements), unfortunately do not seemingly have any business training, personable skills or sense of ethics under their belt to undertake such bouts and in doing so deliver way under an acceptable standard in these areas, whilst making efforts to conceal attempts at enforcing the dark-side.The company does as such:They advertise Unlimited Mobile services and yet the services are very much limited -1. Wildly fluctuating downloads speeds - down to minimal speeds (they do pick up as well; hence the two-star rating)2. Huge latency figures (a known issue)3. Bandwidth that is so narrow that one cannot make a phone-call and be on the internet at the same time4. Dystopian rule (we are not sons and daughters of their clonèd regime)Personal experiences:When asking for a 'letter of deadlock' was told that a gratuity they had GIVEN and of which I made sure - in writing - was a gift-of-no-clauses, stated they would retrieve the fifty-pounds (already-banked) by force if I requested a 'letter of deadlock' in order to take the company up on the bandwidth issue.They came up with the resolution, to grant a piece of equipment that might help to widen the bandwidth and after I checked with their technical team as to whether this equipment would actually sort out the problem, and to which I received an affirmative, the offer was retracted, Vodafone continuing to refuse making satisfaction.Their advertising does not stipulate that Mobile Hotspotting will consist of poor performance but instead makes out that one is getting a super package for the price when in fact the amount is approaching the price for a broadband and phone deal that some (other) companies offer.I am fairly convinced that there is deliberate and secret capping of services as the company tries to push customers onto broadband deals instead of the monthly sim-deal accounts because line-broadband deals make more money, i.e:- instead of being an all-inclusive phone and internet deal, customers that are paying for a line-connection (with Vodafone) would have to pay equal to monthly mobile phone and internet prices for broadband-internet alone...plus...whatever else for a phone-line. Many-a-time told there would manifest some kind of resolution, advertising literature for broadband would instead be thrown at me.After having been kept in an online chat for about five to six hours, any ideas whatsoever as to some kind of resolution were voided, except for the (repeated) solution - not initially linked with this complaint - put forward in particular by those representing the company's CEO, to leave the contract free of charge.The problem comes down to the fact that these companies do not respect the duty in their hands to deliver a high standard of service because they do not value the technology that is in their hands at the outset - wrong people in the wrong jobs.Essentially, we are talking about professional advertising that masks back-street trading.

3* for broadband but 0* for all else!Warning: Vodafone deny all responsibility for missing Amazon vouchers!I applied to Vodafone January 2020 because of their well advertised £100 Amazon voucher offer with the claim that I'd receive an email after 120 days for such a voucher.120 days have passed and whilst the fiber broadband has been acceptable (not really surprising because ultimately it's BT that provides the connectivity infrastructure and so that's not physically changed from when I switched from Sky), no Amazon voucher was forthcoming.This was despite it being clearly advertised on the first page of the Vodafone application journey.Having queried this initially with Vodafone they were initially very helpful and indicated the date at which 120 days is met.This however came and went, so my subsequent web chat with Vodafone resulted in them effectively denying all responsibility for the missing voucher - despite it clearly being shown as part of **their** application process; instead trying to suggest that because the offer was provided by the website *from which** I clicked to get into the Vodafone website!In fact they also claimed the offer was non-existent at the time!I don't think that just because the deal was shown on the MoneySavingExpert.com website from which I clicked though to the Vodafone website to apply is at all responsible for honoring the voucher code somehow!Either way it is completely unacceptable for my to chase a voucher that formed part of the original application and thus my contact with them!UPDATE: 06/06/2020 - After getting in touch with Vodafone, and writing this review, and also then chasing the 3rd party voucher provider Vodafone mentioned during my complaint, surprise surprise I received an email from the 3rd party company within hours! Not sure what happened to resolve this, apart from my frustration in having to chase this up myself, but I have increased this review from 2* to 3* as my complaint is now fully resolved; still - I shouldn't have had to complain in the first place (hence no higher rating!)

A variety of plans were mentioned and then the unlimited plan along with a 20% discount was offered which was very interesting indeed.  I gratefully took this offer up.I'm now two weeks later and the whole area that i live in has home broadband connection problems.This is not normally an issue as I would tether from my mobile. This is where what I thought was a fantastic deal, was far from it. My mobile speeds have dropped at least 30mbs making working from home ridiculously difficult. After being on the phone for the faults relating to the home broadband I then spoke to the customer service team to discuss hope they can rectify the speeds, 3 teams later and my options are1. Upgrade to the max unlimited plan, current discount will not be applied2.  downgrade my plan to what I previously had, this has a discount applied and will be retained. No mention of returning handsetor3.  return my handset and go back to my old contract.I will be returning my handset and when the appropriate time comes along will be cancelling all my contracts with Vodafone.I'm not asking for much  just a reasonable speed on a phone contact that I still pay quite a sum for. Returning the phone will also mean I have a branded, new case that is of no use to me, for now.So a phone call that took more than 40 minutes to a customer services teams, with no willingness to retain a customer, is 40 minutes I'll never get back and Vodafone has lost another customer. Whether this is a result of their systems being inflexible or  the people being inflexible I'll never know.23rd July updateI went in my lunch break to The Lock, Swindon with the intent on handing back my phone, the assistant listened to my experience over the weekend with Vodaphones customer service teams and to cut a long story short, with authorisation from the regional manager, I retained my original 20% discount and my speed upgraded. If I could give an independent score for the assistant in Swindon he would look get a 5 star rating.

I signed up to a Vodafone plan through mobiles.co.uk because of a cashback offer on a high data allowance. My company also offers an employee discount on 12-mo Vodafone contracts. So I decided to give it a go.Vodafone have the best network in the UK. The Ofcom network coverage maps demonstrate it pretty well, and I did my own independent testing, and Vodafone came out on top in every place I've visited - 79% any coverage during my regular commute. I get fast speeds and general reliability is more stable than O2 and far superior to 3.There are many issues with Vodafone though:1. Some settings simply cannot be changed without getting in touch with customer service. For example, voicemail was completely inaccessible for months and only by "resetting" the voicemail was it resolved (not sure why it was not setup correctly in the first place, perhaps as I transferred numbers). Other settings also just show errors when trying to change them such as the age restriction bar.2. When changing limits and settings on the website or app, sometimes it ends up changing other settings unintentionally back to their defaults, or, the setting you actually changed reverts back (as if it never applied in the first place).3. Sometimes when trying to access the website just to get my bills, I'd just get an error saying come back later, which happened for a month - whereas the app was able to make changes without issue.4. If you sign up for a new contract with Vodafone with a new SIM card, even if your old contract has already ended, it takes 30 days to transfer your phone number to the new contract. Whereas moving the number to another provider would have taken at most a couple of days. I've managed to get it down to 7 days through threatening to leave, but this is still unacceptable.5. I previously wanted to leave shortly after my first contract ended, and I asked for my PAC code, and received comms about it many times, but never actually received the code. My online account was also unintentionally deleted so could no longer get to my bills or see my plan.6. When I cancelled a retention plan, the comms said I had to return my phone. The phone that I had actually bought myself and was not part of the contract. This is very misleading and other users could end up believing this.7. My experience of in-store staff is mixed - sometimes they were attentive and sometimes not. Though I don't blame this on the company per se.Overall, I'm very pleased with the coverage and data speed, on the fence about price changes, and not happy about customer service. I would be hesitant to recommend.
